article.text: The Syrian opposition now enjoys massive financial support from Gulf states like Saudi Arabia, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates. But whether money can bring an end to the conflict seems doubtful. (03.04.2012) Red Cross chief Jakob Kellenberger was in Damascus on Tuesday, meeting with government officials on the implementation of a daily two-hour cease-fire to allow aid workers to evacuate the wounded and deliver supplies. United States UN ambassador Susan Rice said Monday that the international community must take promises from the Assad regime with a grain of salt. "Past experience would lead us to be skeptical and to worry that over the next several days, that rather than a diminution of the violence we might yet again see an escalation of the violence. We certainly hope that is not so," said Rice. acb/sej (AFP, Reuters) German magazine Focus has won a defamation suit in Greece, relating to its 2010 issue showing the Venus de Milo raising its middle finger. The image sparked a diplomatic crisis and symbolized long-held mutual distrust. James Murdoch has quit as chairman of BSkyB. But he will continue to be part of the company. EU and IMF auditors have released a report on Portugal's economy, praising the country for successful reforms and austerity measures, but also warning of a 2012 recession and rising unemployment. A day after the Syrian government was said to have accepted a deadline on a UN-backed peace plan, the world body says it will meet with Syrian officials to discuss how the cease-fire can be enforced.
